author: mklement0
body:
<sup>Related: #6989</sup>

_Casts_ from _strings_ use the _invariant_ culture whenever the underlying type has a static `::Parse()` method that accepts an `IFormatProvider` parameter.

Surprisingly, the `-as` operator does _not_ exhibit this behavior and instead exhibits _culture-sensitive_ behavior, but does so _inconsistently_.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
[cultureinfo]::CurrentCulture = 'fr-FR'

[double] '1,2.3'
'1,2.3' -as [double]

[datetime] '10/20/2018 1:22:33 AM'     # OK, invariant culture is used.
'10/20/2018 1:22:33 AM' -as [datetime] # Yields $null, because the *current* culture is used.
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
12,3
12,3

samedi 20 octobre 2018 01:22:33
samedi 20 octobre 2018 01:22:33
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
12,3
12,3
samedi 20 octobre 2018 01:22:33
# !! No output, because the string wasn't recognized as a date.
```

That is, `-as [datetime]` only works with strings that are formatted according to the rules of the _current_ culture; `'20 octobre 2018 01:22:33' -as [datetime]` would work, for instance.

By contrast, `'1,2.3'` _was_ consistently interpreted according to the rules of the _invariant_ culture (where `,` is the grouping char., and `.` the decimal mark; with `fr-FR` in effect, the culture-sensitive `[double]::parse('1,2.3')` would fail).

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core 6.2.0-preview.1 on macOS 10.14
PowerShell Core 6.2.0-preview.1 on Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS
PowerShell Core 6.2.0-preview.1 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; Version 1803, OS Build: 17134.165)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.17134.228 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; Version 1803, OS Build: 17134.345)
```

comments.author: RichardSiddaway
comments.body:
I can confirm this behaviour

I'm using en-GB culture   so dates are day/month/year

```

PS> [datetime]'25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM'
Cannot convert value "25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM" to type "System.DateTime". Error: "String was not recognized as a valid
DateTime."
At line:1 char:1
+ [datetime]'25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM'
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : InvalidCastParseTargetInvocationWithFormatProvider

```

fails as expected. The .NET constructor wants month/day/year so

```
PS> [datetime]'12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM'

25 December 2018 13:00:00

```

This is known .NET related issue since PowerShell v1

The -as operator

```
PS> '25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM' -as [datetime]

25 December 2018 13:00:00

```
accepts and uses the culture specific date format

whereas

'12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM' -as [datetime]

returns null

Checked this on
PowerShell v5.1, v6.1, v6.2 preview 1 on Windows 10 1803 Build 17134.345

My PowerShell v6.1 on WSL uses en-US culture so I get these results


PS /home/Richard> '25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM' -as [datetime]
PS /home/Richard> '12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM' -as [datetime]

Tuesday, December 25, 2018 1:00:00 PM

and

[datetime]'12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM'
[datetime]'25/12/2018 1:00:00 PM'


work as previously shown as expected

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Thanks for confirming the issue, @RichardSiddaway.

> The .NET constructor wants month/day/year so
> This is known .NET related issue since PowerShell v1

It's actually _PowerShell_ that _by design_ opts for interpreting strings using the _invariant culture_, for predictability across cultures.

Also note that there's no _constructor_ involved in this case (there is none that accepts a _string_): PowerShell calls the `[datetime]` type's static `.Parse()` method, and explicitly chooses the overload that allows it to pass the invariant culture as the culture to interpret the input string by.

For instance, behind the scenes,

```powershell
[datetime] '12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM'
```

is effectively translated to:

```powershell
[datetime]::Parse('12/25/2018 1:00:00 PM', [cultureinfo]::InvariantCulture)
```

Also note that, fortunately, it isn't just US-style month-first dates that the invariant culture recognizes; there are formats that are less confusing to international audiences; e.g.:

```powershell
[datetime] '2018-12-25 13:00:00'
```

comments.body: Irrespective of the exact mechanism there is still a mismatch between cast and -as as shown in both sets of examples

Yes, @RichardSiddaway: that's precisely why I opened this issue, and it's what the original post demonstrates.

Note that a similar mismatch affects parameter binding in cmdlets vs. advanced functions - see #6989.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
To make matters worse, I just realized that even the behavior of `-as` itself is internally inconsistent:

E.g., using `-as [double]` is again culture-_invariant_ (I've added an example to the OP) - unlike `-as [datetime]`.

I haven't dug deeper to see what logic underlies this discrepancy.

title: -as operator is unexpectedly selectively culture-sensitive, unlike casts
